Chapter 18: The Road to Rome

Jaén Fortress, Mid-April 1431

The late afternoon sun slanted through the narrow windows of the council chamber, casting long shadows across the maps and documents spread upon the oaken table. The sounds of the military camp beyond the walls—hammering, shouted orders, the ring of steel on steel—formed a constant backdrop to the discussion within.

Don Álvaro de Luna stood with one hand resting on the table, his dark eyes sharp as he considered the question at hand. Across from him, one of Juan's senior advisors leaned forward, frowning at the list of names they'd been compiling.

"The journey to Rome is no small matter," Álvaro said, his voice measured. "Fray Hernando and the qadi—Ahmad—will be carrying documents that could shape the next decade of Christendom's understanding of this crusade. We cannot simply send them on the road like wandering friars."

He glanced toward where Juan sat at the head of the table, then continued: "The converted qadi especially presents... complications. A Muslim scholar who chose baptism after witnessing our victory—Rome will be fascinated, certainly. But the journey itself? There are risks."

The other advisor nodded slowly. "Through Aragon, then Provence, then into Italy. Four, perhaps five weeks of travel. We need men who can protect them, but also men who won't draw excessive attention. A large armed escort might suggest we fear for their safety—which could undermine the message that Ahmad chose conversion freely."

Álvaro's fingers drummed against the table. "And then there's the question of credentials. Safe conduct from us is one thing. But through Aragonese territory? King Alfonso might view this embassy with... interest. Especially after the Infantes' failed revolt."

He paused, meeting Juan's gaze directly. "Your Majesty, we need to consider several questions. First: who travels with them? Fray Hernando is respected, but he's a spiritual advisor, not a diplomat. Ahmad is... well, he's learned and speaks Latin, but he's newly Christian and unfamiliar with European politics. Do we send a secular companion? Someone with diplomatic experience?"

"Second," he continued, ticking off on his fingers, "what guarantees can we provide? Letters bearing your seal certainly. Cardinal Capranica's contacts would help—his network in Rome is extensive, and his associates could watch over them. But what about passage through Aragon? Do we approach King Alfonso directly for safe conduct, or do we rely on our existing diplomatic channels?"

The other advisor interjected: "And timing, Your Majesty. Pope Martin is elderly and unwell. If we delay too long..." He left the implication hanging.

Álvaro nodded grimly. "Yes. Every week we wait is a week the Holy Father might not have. Yet if we rush and something goes wrong—if Ahmad is attacked by bandits, or if Fray Hernando falls ill, or if they're detained at some border crossing—the entire purpose is defeated."

He gestured to the documents on the table. "We have your official report of the victory at Alcalá—seventy conversions, the destruction of the Sultan's army, the fortresses taken. We have your personal letter pledging perpetual crusade service beyond Granada. These are powerful documents. They need to arrive intact, carried by credible witnesses who can testify to what they've seen."

"So the question before us, Your Majesty," Álvaro concluded, "is how do we ensure that happens?"

Two Days Later - Jaén Fortress, Private Chamber

The room was smaller than the grand council hall, more intimate. Late afternoon light filtered through a single window, illuminating the dust motes hanging in the still air. A table had been prepared with wine and bread—simple hospitality for a momentous occasion.

Juan stood near the window as they assembled. Fray Hernando entered first, his gray Franciscan habit dusty from the camp, his weathered face showing the strain of recent weeks but also a quiet determination. Behind him came Ahmad al-Zarqali, dressed now in plain Christian garb—a simple tunic and cloak, no longer the elegant robes he'd worn as qadi. His beard was neatly trimmed, and he carried himself with the dignity of a scholar, though his eyes showed the uncertainty of a man about to walk into an unknown world.

Diego Gómez de Sandoval, Count of Castro followed, a man of perhaps forty years with the careful, watchful eyes of someone who'd learned to read shifting political winds. His dress was appropriate for a diplomatic mission—fine but not ostentatious, marking him as a man of rank without unnecessary display.

Finally came the three guards: weathered veterans in traveling gear, swords at their sides but no heavy armor. Men who could blend into the road traffic of Europe while still being capable of violence if needed.

Álvaro de Luna closed the door behind them and took a position by the wall, witnessing but not central to the moment.

Juan gestured for them to approach the table. "Please, all of you. Sit if you wish, or stand as you prefer. This isn't a formal court ceremony—it's a conversation between men about to undertake something of great importance."

He waited until they'd settled, then continued. "You leave tomorrow at first light for Rome. The journey will take four to five weeks if the weather and roads cooperate. You carry with you documents that will shape how Christendom understands this crusade—not just this year, but for decades to come."

Juan picked up a sealed leather case from the table. "This contains three items. First, my official military report to His Holiness Pope Martin V. The victory at Alcalá, the conversions, the fortresses taken. The facts of what we've accomplished."

He set it down and picked up a smaller, more ornate case. "Second, my personal letter to the Holy Father. Sealed separately, marked for his eyes only. In it, I've pledged myself to perpetual crusade service—not just completing the reconquista, but carrying the Church's banner wherever it's needed after Granada falls. To Africa, against the Ottomans, wherever Christ's cause requires champions."

His eyes moved to each of them in turn. "These letters mean nothing without credible witnesses. That's why you travel together—not just as couriers, but as testimony itself."

He turned to Fray Hernando. "Father, you've been with me since before Rome. You witnessed my audience with Pope Martin, you carried the True Cross into battle at Alcalá, you saw the Sultan's army broken and the conversions that followed. When you speak to the cardinals, you speak as one who was there. They'll believe you because you have no reason to lie and every reason to tell the truth carefully."

Fray Hernando bowed his head slightly. "I will testify to what I have seen, Your Majesty. Nothing more, nothing less."

Juan nodded, then looked at Ahmad. The former qadi met his gaze steadily, though there was nervousness there too.

"Ahmad," Juan said quietly, "you are the living proof of what this crusade can achieve. A qadi who led morning prayers for the Sultan's victory, then chose baptism after witnessing God's judgment. When Rome sees you, hears your story, understands your journey—they'll know this is more than just warfare. It's transformation."

He paused, choosing his words carefully. "But I'll be honest with you. The journey will be difficult in ways you may not expect. You'll travel through Christian lands where many have never met a converted Muslim. Some will be fascinated. Some will be suspicious. A few may be hostile, though Diego and the guards will protect you."

"My advice," Juan continued, "is to present yourself as you are now—a Christian. Not a Muslim wearing a thin Christian veneer, but a man who has embraced the faith genuinely. The clothing you wear now is appropriate. Speak openly about your journey, your doubts, your reasons for choosing Christ. Don't hide your past, but don't cling to it either. When Rome meets you, let them see a man transformed, not a man divided."

Ahmad's voice was quiet but firm. "I understand, Your Majesty. I... I am still learning what it means to be Christian. But I chose this path freely. That much I can testify to without any doubt."

"That's all anyone can ask," Juan said gently. Then he turned to Diego Gómez de Sandoval.

"Count Diego. You're the head of this embassy. Fray Hernando provides spiritual guidance, Ahmad provides living testimony, but you navigate the political waters. You make the decisions about routes, about when to speak and when to stay silent, about which doors to knock on and which to avoid."

Diego inclined his head. "I understand, Your Majesty. I've prepared as best I can—studied the route, memorized Álvaro's contacts, reviewed what we know of the current situation in Rome. But I'll be honest: much will depend on circumstances we can't predict."

"That's why I chose you," Juan replied. "You have the judgment to adapt. A few things to remember: Pope Martin is elderly and ill. Time is critical—don't dawdle, but don't rush so much you attract suspicion or risk the documents. Cardinal Orsini is the Pope's closest advisor; present yourselves to him first. He knows me from my visit two years ago. Trust his guidance on how to approach the Holy Father."

He picked up another sealed letter. "This is for Cardinal Orsini specifically, reminding him of our meeting and asking him to facilitate your audience. Cardinal Capranica's network will also help—Álvaro will give you the relevant names and locations."

Diego accepted the letter with both hands. "We'll treat these documents as we'd treat relics, Your Majesty. They'll reach Rome intact, or we won't reach Rome at all."

Juan smiled faintly. "I'd rather you reach Rome intact as well, Diego. Don't be reckless. These letters are important, but you're also valuable—all of you."

He turned to address all of them together. "You have letters of safe conduct bearing my seal, declaring you to be on official diplomatic mission to the Holy See. In most circumstances, that should be sufficient. But if you encounter serious trouble—if someone powerful tries to detain you, if Aragonese authorities create difficulties—use your judgment. The mission is important, but your lives matter too."

Juan paused, then added more quietly: "One more thing. You're traveling through Aragon. King Alfonso... well, his brothers tried to rebel against me and failed. He may view this embassy with interest, or suspicion, or both. My advice is to be respectful if you encounter his officials, but don't volunteer more information than necessary. You're traveling to Rome on crusade business. That's true, and it's all they need to know."

He looked at each of them again. "Do any of you have questions? Concerns? Now is the time to voice them."

The Following Morning - Jaén, Eastern Walls

The embassy departed at first light, as planned. From the fortress walls, one could watch them until they disappeared into the olive groves heading northwest—five travelers on horseback, a packhorse carrying supplies and the precious sealed letters, becoming smaller and smaller until the morning mist swallowed them entirely.

Now, mid-morning, Álvaro finds Juan in the war room. The camp beyond continues its organized chaos—thousands of troops drilling, supply wagons arriving, the constant activity of an army preparing for imminent deployment.

"They're away cleanly," Álvaro reports. "No incidents, good weather for travel. With fortune, they'll reach Zaragoza in four days, then into Navarre and France beyond."

He sets down a new stack of dispatches on the table. "But we have more immediate matters requiring your attention, Your Majesty. Three items, in order of urgency."

He picks up the first document. "Master of Calatrava's latest report from the Íllora siege. He's... frustrated. The fortress is proving more difficult than anticipated. He's requesting additional siege equipment or permission to attempt an assault. His exact words were 'sitting here bleeding men to guerrilla raids while accomplishing nothing is poor use of fifteen thousand troops.'"

The second dispatch. "From Rodrigo at Vélez-Málaga. He's secured the port and asks for strategic direction—should he consolidate his position, or does he have permission to push toward another target? He notes the fleet is still in excellent condition and his men are eager."

The third document is a letter bearing an unfamiliar seal. "This arrived yesterday from Granada. It's... unusual. A personal letter addressed to you from someone claiming to be a senior merchant in the Sultan's court. He requests safe passage to Jaén to discuss 'matters of mutual benefit.' Could be genuine, could be an intelligence probe, could be an assassination plot. But it's written in quite good Latin and shows detailed knowledge of our recent movements."

Álvaro sets the documents down and looks at Juan directly. "Your Majesty, the campaign is reaching a decision point. Íllora is bleeding us slowly. Vélez-Málaga offers opportunities but needs direction. And this merchant letter... well, that requires your judgment on whether to even respond."

The embassy's five weeks in Rome proved extraordinary, though not without complexity.

The Papal Audience

Pope Martin V, though visibly weakened by illness and age, received the embassy three days after their arrival. Cardinal Orsini facilitated the audience personally, and his presence signaled to the Curia that this was a matter of importance.

The meeting took place in a private chamber rather than formal audience hall—a concession to the Pope's frailty, but also creating intimacy that worked in the embassy's favor. Martin V sat propped by cushions, his breathing labored, but his mind remained sharp.

Fray Hernando presented the official military report first, describing the Battle of Alcalá in measured terms. The Pope listened intently, occasionally asking clarifying questions about tactics and casualties. When Hernando reached the account of the Sultan's army breaking and fleeing, Martin V's eyes brightened.

Then came the conversions. The Pope leaned forward as Hernando described the seventy warriors choosing baptism, the qadi's theological crisis, the spontaneous professions of faith. "Seventy souls," Martin V whispered. "Seventy Muslims who saw God's judgment and chose truth."

Diego presented Juan's personal letter—sealed, marked for the Pope's eyes only. Martin V broke the seal himself and read in silence, his weathered hands trembling slightly as he held the parchment. When he finished, he looked up with tears in his eyes.

"He pledges himself to perpetual crusade," the Pope said quietly to Cardinal Orsini. "Not just Granada. Africa. The Ottomans. Wherever the Church needs champions. This... this is what we prayed for. A king who understands."

The audience lasted nearly two hours—far longer than the Pope's physicians recommended. He asked detailed questions about the campaign, the conversions, Juan's character and faith. Fray Hernando's testimony carried enormous weight; the Pope remembered him from Juan's 1430 visit and trusted his judgment.

Before dismissing them, Martin V spoke directly to the embassy: "Tell your king that he has our complete confidence and blessing. Tell him that God's hand is clearly upon this crusade. Tell him that we will ensure all Christendom knows what he has accomplished."

Ahmad's Examination

The Curia's response to Ahmad al-Zarqali was fascination mixed with intense scrutiny.

Over ten days, Ahmad was examined by various cardinals, theologians, and church scholars. They questioned him about Islamic theology, his reasons for conversion, whether he'd been coerced, his understanding of Christian doctrine, his intentions going forward.

Ahmad handled it remarkably well. He was honest about his doubts, his intellectual crisis after the battle, his genuine search for truth. He didn't claim perfect understanding of Christianity—only that he'd recognized Islam's answers were insufficient and chosen to seek truth in Christ. His scholarly background and evident sincerity convinced most questioners.

Several cardinals became genuine advocates. Cardinal Domenico Capranica (who'd helped Juan in 1430) was particularly enthusiastic, seeing Ahmad as proof that crusade could achieve spiritual transformation rather than just military conquest. Others saw propaganda value—a converted qadi was a powerful symbol.

There were skeptics, certainly. A few cardinals questioned whether the conversion would last, whether Ahmad truly understood Christianity, whether he might revert to Islam once away from Christian authority. But even the skeptics acknowledged his testimony was compelling and his presence in Rome generated enormous interest.

By the second week, Ahmad had become something of a sensation. Scholars wanted to debate theology with him. Artists sketched him. Chroniclers interviewed him. The story of the qadi who led prayers for the Sultan's victory, then converted after witnessing God's judgment, spread through Rome like wildfire.

The Curia's Response

Cardinal Orsini orchestrated a broader presentation before an assembly of cardinals in the third week. Diego, Fray Hernando, and Ahmad all spoke. The response was overwhelmingly positive.

Several factors worked in Juan's favor:

Political Timing: With Pope Martin clearly dying, cardinals were thinking about legacy. Supporting a successful crusade made them look good and aligned them with what might be Martin V's final great accomplishment.

The Conversion Narrative: Ahmad's story provided exactly what Rome wanted—proof that crusade could save souls, not just conquer territory. It validated the entire crusading ideology at a moment when some questioned its relevance.

Juan's Reputation: The cardinals remembered the 18-year-old king who'd stripped naked before the Pope and pledged everything to the crusade. That he'd actually delivered on his promises impressed them deeply.

Strategic Implications: A successful reconquista would free Castilian military power for other crusades—potentially against North Africa or even supporting eastern campaigns against the Ottomans. Cardinals saw Juan as a long-term asset.

Not everyone was enthusiastic. Cardinals with Aragonese connections were more reserved, conscious of the political complications between Juan and King Alfonso V. A few questioned whether Juan's ambitions were sustainable or represented youthful overreach. But the majority were clearly supportive.

After five weeks in Rome, the embassy departed in mid-June 1431 with substantial results:

1. Formal Papal Letter (Public)

A letter from Pope Martin V to King Juan II, written in the Pope's own hand despite his weakness, suitable for public circulation:

The letter praises Juan's victory at Alcalá in effusive terms, calling it "a triumph not merely of arms but of faith." It commends the conversions as evidence of divine favor and describes Juan as "a model of Christian kingship in an age that desperately needs such examples."

Critically, it explicitly validates Juan's broader crusading ambitions: "Just as you have shown yourself faithful in the reconquest of Iberia, so too do we trust you shall prove faithful in carrying Christ's banner wherever the Church has need—to Africa, against the Ottoman threat, and in defense of Christians everywhere."

A shorter, more personal letter from Martin V to Juan alone:

The tone is warm, almost fatherly. The Pope expresses profound gratitude that Juan kept his word and delivered results beyond what Martin dared hope. He acknowledges his own approaching death and says seeing this crusade succeed gives him peace.

It's a dying man's blessing to someone he believes will carry forward his legacy.

Within months, all of Christendom will know about King Juan II of Castile's victory, the converted qadi, and the crusade that's actually achieving spiritual transformation.

Jaén Fortress - Mid-April 1431, Late Afternoon

A courier arrived in the courtyard, his horse lathered and exhausted. The man himself looked haggard, mud-splattered, and moved with the urgency of someone bearing bad news. Within minutes, Álvaro de Luna was reading the dispatch in the war room, his face darkening with each line.

He looked up at Juan. "Your Majesty... it's from the Master of Calatrava. The siege of Íllora." His voice was tight. "It's not good."

He handed over the letter. The parchment bore the seal of the Military Order of Calatrava, but the wax was hastily applied, suggesting speed over ceremony.

Letter from Don Pedro González de Padilla, Master of Calatrava

To His Majesty King Juan II of Castile, at Jaén

Written this 14th day of April, Year of Our Lord 1431, from the siege lines before Íllora

Your Majesty,

I write with the burden of reporting a grave setback to our operations against Íllora fortress. What began as a methodical siege has deteriorated into a crisis that demands your immediate attention and decision.

The Situation:

We invested Íllora three weeks ago with confidence. Our fifteen thousand troops established siege lines, Master Gunner Pietro positioned his bombards, and initial bombardment commenced as planned. The outer walls showed promising damage within the first week—two breaches were opened in the curtain wall facing our main approach.

On the night of April 11th, everything changed.

A Moorish force—we estimate between eight hundred and one thousand raiders—struck our camp in a coordinated assault of exceptional sophistication. They came in three columns simultaneously: one against our powder magazine, one against the artillery positions, and one against the eastern picket line. The attack came during the changing of the night watch, exploiting a moment of transition with precision that suggests detailed intelligence of our routines.

The Damage:

The powder magazine was their primary target. They used fire—Greek fire or something similar, based on how it burned. We lost approximately two-thirds of our gunpowder reserves before we could contain the blaze. What remains is sufficient for perhaps five to seven more days of bombardment at reduced intensity, certainly not enough to complete the siege.

Two of Master Pietro's five bombards were damaged—not destroyed, but rendered temporarily inoperable. One took a direct hit from burning debris that cracked the barrel. The other's carriage was demolished. Pietro believes he can repair both given time and materials, but not here, not now, not under these conditions.

We suffered between four hundred and five hundred casualties—dead, wounded, or missing. Many of our artillery crews were killed defending the guns. The Moorish raiders withdrew before dawn, taking minimal casualties themselves, and melted back into the hills.

Current Status:

Morale among the troops has collapsed. Men who were confident three days ago now look over their shoulders constantly. The Moors demonstrated they can strike us at will, and our soldiers know it. Discipline is holding, but barely. I have executed two men for refusing picket duty and flogged a dozen more for dereliction. It has helped, but fear is spreading faster than I can contain it.

We attempted two assaults on the breaches we'd opened, hoping to capitalize on our earlier bombardment before the garrison could repair the damage. Both were repulsed with heavy losses—another eighty dead, perhaps one hundred fifty wounded. The defenders fought with desperate courage, and without adequate artillery support to suppress their positions during the assault, we could not press home the advantage.

Worse still, our scouts report a relief force approaching from the south—perhaps two to three thousand troops, possibly Moroccan mercenaries or forces scraped together from Granada's southern garrisons. They are perhaps three to five days' march away. If they arrive before we can restore our siege effectiveness, we will be caught between a garrison that has proven resilient and a relief force at our backs.

Supply line harassment continues unabated. We lose five to fifteen men daily to ambushes on our supply trains. The guerrilla campaign is bleeding us slowly but steadily.

My Assessment:

Your Majesty, I have served the Military Orders for twenty-three years. I have commanded sieges in Andalusia and fought the Moors in a dozen campaigns. I do not write this lightly: we are failing here.

Without adequate powder, without full artillery capability, facing constant harassment and now a relief force approaching, I cannot take this fortress in any reasonable timeframe. Every day we remain costs us men and morale. The troops are exhausted, frightened, and increasingly convinced this siege is cursed.

I see three options before us:

First: Send immediate reinforcement—perhaps five thousand troops from the reserve at Alcalá, along with additional powder supplies and materials to repair the bombards. With fresh troops and restored artillery, we might yet take Íllora before the relief force arrives or defeat that force when it comes. But this commits more resources to what has already proven a costly operation.

Second: Withdraw in good order before the relief force arrives, preserving our army for operations elsewhere. This is a defeat, and the Moors will trumpet it across Granada. But we preserve fifteen thousand troops who can be deployed more profitably. The siege has cost us perhaps six hundred casualties already—withdrawal prevents that number from doubling or tripling in a desperate fight against both fortress and relief force.

Third: Attempt one massive assault before the relief force arrives—throw everything at the breaches simultaneously, accept heavy casualties, but try to overwhelm the garrison through sheer weight of numbers before we're caught between two forces. This is desperate and will cost us dearly in blood, but it might succeed if God favors us and the garrison's morale breaks.

My Recommendation:

Your Majesty, I reluctantly recommend withdrawal. This siege has become a trap. We lack the resources to complete it properly, and the approaching relief force threatens to turn this into a disaster far worse than what we've already suffered. Better to preserve our army intact and redeploy to targets where we can achieve success.

However, I am your servant and the servant of this crusade. If you judge that Íllora must be taken regardless of cost, I will see it done or die in the attempt. If you can send reinforcement swiftly, perhaps we can salvage this operation. If you order withdrawal, I will conduct it in good order and ensure we inflict maximum damage on our way out.

I await your orders with all urgency. The relief force marches, our powder dwindles, and our men's courage frays by the hour. Whatever your decision, it must be made swiftly.

May God guide your judgment in this dark hour.

Your faithful servant in Christ,

Don Pedro González de Padilla
Master of the Order of Calatrava

Documents reveal entire sortie plan: 2,500-3,000 troops will pour from western gate when Sultan refuses demand. Explicit goal: 'Kill or capture the Christian king.' Courier confirms authenticity.
rolls.evaluation: Near-maximum roll. Transforms the situation completely — Juan now knows every detail of the Sultan's plan and can set a counter-trap.
